A fantastic port that does almost everything right.  It's the same FFX you know and love, but with a fresh coat of paint. Assuming you liked it on the PS2, you'll be able to fall in love all over again with the PC version.  Let me start with the cons, as they are few but still annoying.  - Still no ability to skip cut scenes. - The minigames are still terrible. - Inputting Auron's overdrive prompts on a non-PS2 controller has been clumbsy. - It's the same game, so if you hated it back in the day, you'll still hate it now. - Seriously, why can't we skip cutscenes?  Really, that's it. Now for the overwhelming pros.  - Runs smoothly, without issue. Immediately recognized my controller, had no crashes or freezes or even any bugs. - Runs QUICKLY. The PS3 Remastered version had load times, not long ones, but still noticeable, especially when entering several different rooms at once; you'd see the spinning Jecht symbol and have to wait five seconds. This version has none of that. Much faster. - Remastered textures. The games looks better than ever (though little if any different from the PS3/4 remastered versions). - Additional content (compared to US PS2 version). You can now fight the Dark Aeons and Penace, as well as use minor new abilities and equipment, not to mention the Expert Sphere Grid. - PC Perks. At the press of a button, you can have no random encounters or one every two steps; you can speed the gameplay up x2 or x4; you can even enter a 'cheat mode' where you have max stats. This speeds things up so much. Farming for the monster area? Turn on turbo and more encounters and you'll be done in less than half the time. Fantastic. - The Creature Creator in FFX2 deserves a special shoutout. Yes, FFX2 is an abomination, yada yada, I know ... but Creator Creature is fun! You can access it after the introduction and just go to town. It almost makes the rest of the game less disasterific. - Can choose between original or the enhanced soundtrack, and the original or expert sphere grids. - Still the same game, so if you loved it back in the day, you'll feel the same today.  This is the forth time I've bought a version of FFX, and this is the best version, hands-down. How often can you say that about a port of a console game?

I am very glad that this day came and now I am able to repeat the experience on my computer. I can recommend this game with all of my heart. I am aware that huge part of my praise is caused because of the nostalgia, but you have to believe me that Final Fantasy X is worth playing. In my opinion the battle system in FFX is one of the best that was used in FF franchise, and the sphere grid system is also very well thought as it allows you to mix abilities as you like. When it comes to the port, I was afraid that it would be ruined, but luckily I was wrong. The game works very well and I have not experienced any problems thus far.  What is more the HD remaster looks very nice and I can't say anything bad about it. When it comes to me, this game is far better than most of the new FF's, so I will repeat myself to tell you again that I truly recommend it.  As for the FFX-2, I honestly cannot say that it is a bad game. It may not be as brilliant as FFX, but it is not a total mistake either. Do I have to add that it also has a very beautiful soundtrack?  To sum up, I say: go for this game! Discover the beauty within it, experience the beautiful music and help Yuna and others in their quest.

As a long time fan of the series, FFX was one of whcih that I had to get as soon as it recieved its HD treament and was availble on PC. At the time of its initial release, the quality of graphics and gameplay was at the top of all others, possibly the best on the PS2. After all those years, this game still holds up in terms of gameplay. The game features a turn based system, that incorporates more strategic actions requiring the player to understand that each character is built around the idea that they are a specific counter to certain enemies. Taking that into consideration the system creates a situation in which every battle will require a different party composition per enemy groups encountered.  In terms of story, we begin with our protagonist thrown into a group that is just about to embark on a journey to save the world from a seemingly natural calamity. (possible spoilers ahead) Originating from a very modern world, the player is able to empathize with the protagonist as he inquires about this new world with antiquated technologies and traditions. However, as he learns more about the world, he finds that this world seems to hold things that belonged to the world he came from. A city known as Zanakand is also in this world, the Blitzball victory pose has turn into a prayer pose for the dominant religion, and most notably a man named Jecht, the father of the protagonist who turned missing for a decade, is now a well known hero whom perished in battle, also a decade prior.

This is one of my favorite games ever and I'm sooooooooooo glad it finally came to the PC, I almost never thought it would happen, and it's even better than I ever thought it could be on PC.  Originally I already bought this on PS3 and it was already great-looking with amazing nostalgic value there but this version takes everything I liked about the PS3 HD Remaster and makes it even better, like including both the original music and the fancy new arrangement music to switch between. They originally wanted to do this on the PS3 version as well but didn't bother due to size restraints.  This game is very stable and well optimized for any modern 1st-day PC release, let alone a PC port from Square Enix. They really put some work in with this one. There's a real menu when you hit escape instead of just opening a jarring 'Close Window?' prompt in a Windows UI box appearing over the game as with many other FF games. The aformentioned pause menu has an ACTUAL IN-GAME GRAPHICS SETTINGS MENU!!!!!! It's got MSAA options, SMAA options, texture options, shadow options and a few others. I personally have the settings maxed out and it looks great. I play it on 1440p and the textures are incredible considering it's a 15 year old game originally made for Standard Definition screens now being played on an extremely large but relatively uncommon resolution above the typical 1080p that the HD Remaster was probably optimized for already on PS3/4. Presumably this means 4K will look great as well for those with such monitors. So far no crashing at all and only some minor choppiness in areas that have a lot going on such as in Al Bhed Home, which is perfectly normal and expected.  The XBox One controller actually works perfectly as well. Final Fantasy VIII didn't work with controllers at all, Final Fantasy IX had controller support but it was so dysfunctional I couldn't even play the game. This game has perfect controller support and using it feels natural: everything just works, and there's no weirdly mapped buttons. The game also uses actual XBox controller buttons in the UI for explanations instead of defaulting to keyboard keys.  My only issues are really small ones, mostly that some minor things about the gameplay weren't addressed in the Remastering process, like the inconvenient inability to exchange spheres in cloister puzzles instead of having to find a slot to leave one sphere so you could pick up the other. It would've been nice of them to acknowledge how tedious these puzzles are and improve it just a little bit sort of like they did with the booster options, but it would've required new animations I think. Also the Blitzball automatic movement AI is awful, passing to your ideal shooter on the left side doesn't mean they will try to get between defenders and get closer to the goal for an angled shot and only having to deal with a defender or two, or possibly even having an open shot. Instead, they still instantly move backwards diagonally towards the middle and seem to try gathering up as many opposing team players as possible so you're having to shoot/pass/breakthrough in quadruple coverage from center field. Honestly I didn't expect them to fix these things anyway though, it just would've made the game that much closer to perfection.  Any PC gamer who liked Final Fantasy X back in the day on PS2, I would strongly recommend this game to them. It's really not the same lazy quality port as all the other Final Fantasy ports, they did a very good job on this game and I consider it to be the definitive FFX experience.

2 Final Fantasy games in one; FFX - Boy gets pulled into a world of chaos, boy meets girl, family drama, what could go wrong? There are some additions to the original game; Creature Creator - capture and train creatures (FFX-2), put them in your party and they'll auto-fight along side you! Cheat options added in (F1/2/3/4) for on the spot encounter rate, character boosts, max gill etc (FFX/FFX-2). AutoSaves - with an adorably cute and animated chocobo icon. Random bits pulled in from international console versions; Dark Aeons (FFX) Expert Sphere Grid (FFX) Possibly other things I haven't noticed yet.  Square Enix seems to have improved a bit; the game seems stable, pretty, scales well on our 4K TV and actually plays properly, which is more to be said of previous ports. Texture stretching during animations (eye iris's stretching for example)... seems to be the only major grind I have with it and even then, it's rare.  For extra 'spice', also works with ReShade (DX11) to flavor out the graphics a little more.  They get one good review from me finally, at least for effort. I can actually play this and it works well with SteamLink.

'Final Fantasy X/X-2 HD Remaster' on Steam is a very good port. Especially if we're comparing to XIII and XIII-2 (which I still enjoy). Graphically, it looks amazing, even at 1366x768. As added bonuses, exclusive to this version, are 'Boosters'. These toggles allow for 2x/4x speed (great for traveling far quickly without a chocobo), 'Supercharge' is good as well, which charges your character's overdrive meters each turn and heals them periodically. 'More Encounters/No Encounters' is self-explanatory enough, you are able to control the game's random encounter rate to help with grinding or avoiding needless battles. An 'Auto-Battle' feature has also been added to have an AI control your characters in battle. Though this usually limits them to basic attacks, no magic or items. 'Hide HUD' does was it says as well. Next, is the 'cheats' that work similar to a trainer program. Enabling these can Max out your character's skills, Gil, and give you 99 of all items in the game, excluding Key/Mission Items. The game is locked at 30 FPS which apparently bothers people. Doesn't bother me since this is exactly how it was on the PS2/3/4/Vita, so I have no reason to expect more. FFX-2 is relatively stable as well, other than a strange bug that happens when attempting to pause using the keyboard, the game crashes entirely. Pausing with a controller works fine. Just don't play X-2 with keyboard controls and you'll be fine.

Final Fantasy X/X-2 HD Remaster on PC is probably the definitive version of both games for you to play. Final Fantasy X for me is one of the best JRPG's of all time for various reasons: the world of Spira is rich and diverse; it has a great story, even if sometimes some things don't make much sense; the cast is rich; the combat system is old school, but that's the reason why i like it: turn based combat; to win battles you'll need different strategies even for normal encounters; leveling up through a grid allows for more customization; the soundtrack is simply amazing. Although there are a few things that i don't really like: idle party members don't gain AP; the minigames are crap (except for blitzball); the areas are mostly corridors, and there's no airship; you still can't skip cutscenes (why?). But still, it's a great game that alone deserves you to buy this collection. And you get all the international version content (extra superbosses and a X-2 prologue). It's worth it. And then there's Final Fantasy X-2. As a whole, i actually like this game, but i understand most of the criticism this game has: it's a fanservice cashgrab; the map is mostly recycled from X; it has almost no story, and what's here isn't much interesting; it's mostly a side-quest galore (but better that the ones in X, although blitzball here kinda sucked for me); the cast is less interesting; the soundtrack sucks (with some exceptions). It seems that the best thing this game has is the combat, going back to the ATB system and adding a class change mechanic mid-combat. It has a lot of options, but for me it's almost pointless, since most of the strategy from X was removed. With a few exceptions, you can beat most of the game by just using the normal attack and healing with Hi-Potions without too much trouble. But despite all this, it's still an enjoyable game, only not as good as X. And this international version adds a lot of content. First, there's the creature capture where you can capture and use monsters in combat, even if you don't have control over them. Leveling them up unlocks a mini story with a cutscene. Many monsters have cutscenes to unlock, and if you watch them all there's around 4-6 hours of extra movies. They are silly, but made me laugh. Secondly, there's the Final Mission, a rogue-like dungeon turn-based game that serves as an epilogue to X-2. And i was surprised by it. It's not a minigame, but almost an entire game that will take you around 10-20 hours to beat. It has an incredible amount of depht for what it is. It stars easy, but becomes hard if you don't have a solid strategy. Fortunately, there's plenty of good options, and i enjoyed playing it. This remaster also adds an audio drama epilogue, and it's bad. It's 30 minutes of screwing with the story of X. Just terrible. This PC version also includes some in-game cheats like superspeed and auto-battle (great for grinding) and an auto-save that saves you a lot of trouble, trust me. It makes the games a little easier, but they are optional. It has a 30 FPS cap, but it works just fine. It will run on almost all PC's, and i never experienced slowdown or a crash. The download size is big though. In the end, this is a great package that includes 2 entire games (one great and one good) and a lot of extras including an extra game. On your PC. And the price is also fair for what you get.

Visuals 8/10: The new HD is nice, I always thought the characters looked a little funky in Cinematics but the visuals have aged quite well, considering.  Audio 8/10: I remember every song in Final Fantasy 7, and 8. This one... not completely memorable, but there are a few songs that hold quite a lot of emotion, and meaning in them. Uematsu does good work. The talking sometimes got on my nerves because of their mouths moving when their voices were stopped [Nitpicking perhaps, pet peeve of mine] but considering it's the first voice-acted of the series, it's a pretty damn good start.  Gameplay 7/10: I love the ability to switch to any teammate during combat, and the overdrives are pretty neat. That being said there were a lot of annoying mini-games [The temples] and one that is complete hit or miss for most [Blitzball].  Characters 7/10: I don't feel an intense amount of 'rite of passage' for many of the characters, there was no gradual change only immediate ones, which in a game of this length I feel as if some characters at least should have a slow change, especially in a 'fish out of water' scenario.  Story 9/10: I didn't feel as strong about the events in this as some of my favorite Final Fantasies, but I still teared up at the end. Even though it's not my favorite Final Fantasy, this is still a period when Squaresoft really knew how to wrap up games and leave you watching credits hoping for more. There were characters I was sad to see go through a few things [Sorry, no spoilers] but there was still some closure for those characters.  Overall 8/10 : Holds up well for as long as it's been out. Pretty different from the few Final Fantasies before it [the world at least]. As much as it wasn't my favorite, as I said I was still sad to see the journey end, and debateably as abruptly as it did. Definitely worth a look for any JRPG fan.  That being said, I haven't played X-2 and in truth I don't know if I will, but if I do I will review it. Port review only. 10/10  I hate people that post reviews just to brag about their build but there's some things you need to know.  My experience with this port so far has been amazing but I'm able to crank it up to 4k and play it on high. It looks great and plays smooth. I'm running a i5-4760k and SLI GTX 970 FTWs on Windows 10. I only overclock my CPU and RAM. I've heard some complaints about multiple GPU performance but have not experienced any issues myself. I'm running the most recent GeForce drivers. I would recommend turning down your GPU to stock and make sure you have the latest drivers if you have any issues. Some games don't do well overclocked because the GPU has to wait for other processes to be complete before turning the next frame. That means, if you crank up your GPU...it just ends up waiting longer which can cause issues. Some chipsets don't work well together either. It's worth knowing you have a chipset specifically for your GPU.  I'm a fan of orchestrated music and this port allows you to use the arranged score in play of the original soundtrack. They knocked it out of the park with this function. The arranged score is beautiful and fits in perfect.  The gameplay is stable (on a stable system) and I've had no tearing, freezing, skipping, nor found any bugs to complain about up to Luca (haven't been xping much if at all). I'll update once I'm through the story.  While the graphics settings only offer low, medium, and high...you can tweak settings through the Nvidia control panel if you are running on a lower resolution but want to smooth textures through antialiasing. Good detail in shadows and lighting without messing with anything. Increased environment detail. Huge improvements on the original and leagues above the console HD versions if you have a powerful enough PC.  You can play on both the original and expert sphere grids. Expert can be fun just to mix things up a bit if you've ran through the game at least once already.  I don't use the game boosters but you can speed up gameplay, turn off random encounters (might use that one later), get unlimited money, unlock all skills, and always full overdrive meter.  Great port for a great game. Hope this helps.

This game is amazing. Im only 20 hours into the game but I can already say that Final Fantasy X is the best turn based rpg I have ever played. If you like turn based rpgs, you will like this game. This game also comes with Final Fantasy X-2 so the value you get for buying the game for $30 is good. The amount of time you can put into either game more than justifies the price. The battle system in Final Fantasy 10 is one of my personal favorite turn based battle systems. One problem I often run into during turn based battle systems is that it does not really matter what people you choose to use in battle. This is not a problem in Final Fantasy X because each person has a distinct role in the game so what people you bring into battle has a big effect on the chance you have at winning that fight. The level up system in Final Fantasy X is also intresting. When you win battles you get points and once you get a certain amount of points you get a step. Once you have a step you can use it to move around a grid full of spheres that you can put orbs in (almost all monsters in the game drop orbs) that will raise your stats or give you new skills. So the more steps you get the more orbs you can activate. It is an intresting system that allows you to control character growth. When starting the game you have the option to use the standard or expert sphere grid and the diffrence between the two is that the standard grid puts you a set path durning the start of the game which gives that charecter its role. The expert grid allows you to put any charecter down any role giving you the most freedom. However, it is harder to max out your stats on the expert grid so if you want to play post game you might want to pick the standard grid. But overall this game is really good and I would recommend it to people who love turn based battle systems. If you are new to turn based battle systems this game is a good place to start but I would highly recommend going down the standard grid.

This game is my all time favorite game. It has a great cast of characters, an engaging story and great RPG gameplay. The soundtrack is one of the best out there (the remastered tracks can be hit or miss, but they're mostly good), and the art direction is great (minus a few details in this remaster which were better in the original IMO). Still one of the best RPGs out there, with tons of content to explore and sink hours into. It's a narrative-driven RPG so don't expect too much freedom during the course of the main story (though as usual with Final Fantasies, you'll be able to do as you please in the late game). For this remaster and port in particular, I haven't encountered any issues whatsoever during my 70ish hours of play. Works fine on my end just like it did in the old PS2 back in the day.  Personal Highlights: -Engaging, strategic turn based battle system (it's a bit on the easy side, but still very fun). -Character growth system that was interesting and innovative for its time. If you're a stat-maxer be ready for quite a few hours of grinding. -Good characters and good stories complement each other, this one does it beautifully. To me, the best example of those two done right in the series.  -Music not being done solely by Uematsu can make old fans worry, but then you get to experience it and see the other two composers put their heart into it and it turns into a very cohesive and complementary whole thing. Hamauzu's ambient tracks are amazing, for example.  Cons: -Minigames are more like 'challenges' with Blitzball being the only minigame fully fleshed out. And Blitzball itself is hit or miss. Some people really love it though. The caveat to this is that all of said minigames are entirely optional (except the single mandatory blitzball game that you don't even need to win). -A lot of the post game can be quite time consuming (final weapons' upgrading, capturing monsters, etc.)
Good game. You can easily sink hours and hours into it and with plenty of great minigames to break the monotony.

Having played the original PS2 version of this game, the PS3 remaster and its Vita port, this is easily the best adaption although not tremendously different from the PS3 version and if you own that one I wouldn't necessarily recommend it.   The game's minimum requirements suggest that this is a well optimised port capable of running on the now-antiquated (and midrange for the time) 9600GT, among others. There are a number of graphical settings which I assume run the gamut between the Vita and recent PS4 release, and any surplus of graphical horsepower can be put towards higher resolutions/downsampling and anti-aliasing; I'm running at 4k (1080p display) with 8xMSAA and SMAA, which cleans up any aliasing without distorting the details (although I don't recommend running SMAA or FXAA on less than a 4k resolution unless you have no other option). Props to them for decoupling MSAA and post-process methods, too. The 30 frame lock isn't a problem for this game generally although I recognise that it could cause nausea especially if sitting close to the screen.  Compared to the PS2 version, this has the same gameplay improvements as every subsequent remaster, plus the cheats which include a fast-forward mode that sadly doesn't work for cutscenes. Tidus is still a prick and the voice acting is still poor, something that gives away its position as one of the first (mostly) fully voice-acted JRPGs. The battle system is probably the best of the series. Character progression is relatively non-linear, you have the choice of branching out into other characters' skills or continuing along the obvious progression. Gamepad accessibility issues    The launcher (and settings app) cannot be navigated with a gamepad; must use a mouse.    The system menu in the game can be navigated via gamepad, but not accessed via gamepad. You have to press |Esc| on the keyboard. Final Fantasy X might be my favorite in the series. It's got a unique setting, a great turn-based combat system that demands strategy, and a heartfelt story that once again shows you don't necessarily need happily ever after to have a satisfying conclusion. The graphics hold up well and look great in HD. The music is wonderful and you can choose between the remastered soundtrack or the original version. It's on the linear side though, which I know bothers some folks, and the lack of skippable cutscenes hurts replay value somewhat. I love the story and characters, but it'd be nice to skip over the more boring scenes after a few times through.  Final Fantasy X-2 is a whole different beast. While it has the same setting and some returning characters, it takes place a few years after the original and has a much more light-hearted tone - although there's a story worthy of Final Fantasy underneath its bubbly exterior. It's also got a great take on the series trademark job system and the best version of the classic ATB system to date. Notably, the game abandons its prequel's linearity in favor of a very non-linear structure that lets you tackle things in whatever order you want. This one's hit or miss among fans, but I personally like it.  As for as ports go, it's one of Square's better PC offerings. It runs at a steady framerate - although it's worth mentioning it's locked at 30 FPS - and looks really nice. I never experienced any bugs or crashes, and overall was impressed by the polish of it all after the disappointing FFXIII ports. Plus you're getting two great full-length RPGs for the price of one, which is tough to beat.  I recommend this to anyone looking to revisit these classics and / or wanting more quality JRPGs on their PC.
